Award.AwardTitle: Algebraic, Combinatorial, and Analytic Applications of Symmetric Functions
Award.AbstractNarration:
From the lattice structure of crystals, to states of matter, to matrices and differential operators, the traits of systems and their evolution are classified by symmetries. Algebraic combinatorics studies symmetries via their manifestations in well-known discrete objects like graphs, permutations, and partitions. Its methods have successfully solved problems in other sciences such as physics, computer sciences, and biology. This project concerns the application of algebraic combinatorics, in particular its subfield the theory of symmetric functions, to solve such problems.

This project is centered around the tools used, namely, the theory of symmetric functions and the associated combinatorics. Various complexity problems in representation theory concern the computation of certain structure constants and multiplicities that are expressible via the Kronecker and plethystic coefficients of the symmetric group, which can be defined using Schur functions. In statistical mechanics, the partition functions of some integrable lattice models like lozenge tilings are often Lie group characters, and their asymptotic study reveals probabilistic behavior like Gaussian unitary ensemble eigenvalue distribution near the boundary or the existence of limit shapes and surfaces. This project aims to expand these applications to study other models and distributions. Studying combinatorial and algebraic properties of Schubert polynomials, as representatives of the cohomology classes of flag varieties, can lead to combinatorial interpretations for the corresponding structure constants. Further, computational properties of their stable versions, the Stanley symmetric functions, could lead to understanding of the mysterious limit behavior of random sorting networks, corresponding to the reduced decompositions of permutations into adjacent transpositions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project revolved around the application of Algebraic Combinatorics to the study of problems related to Theoretical Computer Science and Statistical Mechanics, as well as deepening our understanding of fundamental quantities of representation theoretic origins. Such fundamental quantities are the Kronecker coefficients of the Symmetric group and plethysm coefficients for the general linear group, whose combinatorial formula or interpretation is one of the fundamental open problems in Algebraic Combinatorics. Other such problems revolve about the understanding of Schubert polynomials coming from Algebraic Geometry, chromatic symmetric polynomials of Graph theory etc.

At the other end are the fundamental problems of Theoretical CS – the millennium problem of P vs NP, its algebraic variant the VP vs VNP and the general search for theoretical lower bounds of computational models. Geometric Complexity theory (GCT) is a program aimed at studying computational complexity using the symmetries of the universal polynomials (determinant, permanent) and naturally intersecting with the goals and tools of Algebraic Combinatorics described in the Project abstract.  

Among one of the main accomplishments of this project was a fundamental understanding of GCT and its limitations. Together with P. Burgisser and Ch. Ikenmeyer the PI disproved one of the leading conjectures and approaches in GCT – that there exist  “occurrence obstructions” for separating the permanent from a superpolynomially sized determinant and thereby proving VP is not equal to VNP. In the course of this work the PI and collaborators (Ikenmeyer, Gesmundo) established many new facts about the fundamental properties of the mysterious Kronecker and plethysm coefficients. (3 papers)

In a different direction, the PI together with A. Morales and I. Pak developed the Combinatorics of skew semi-Standard Young Tableaux, generalizing a new counting formula, establishing new bijections and connections in Algebraic Combinatorics. Applications of this work included new asymptotic formulas for the number of skew SSYTs in various limit regimes, connections with weighted lozenge tilings, explicit bounds on evaluations of Schubert polynomials, and asymptotic results on Kronecker and Littlewood-Richardson coefficients; leading to the new subfield of Asymptotic Algebraic Combinatorics. (8 papers with subsets Morales, Pak, Yeliussizov) A separate approach via probabilistic methods lead to the asymptotics for the number of partitions inside a rectangle and quantitative refinement of Silverster’s unimodality theorem (with S. Melczer, R. Pemantle)

Other subprojects developed Combinatorics of a new class of Chromatic Symmetric polynomials and connections with LLT polynomials (with P. Alexandersson) and separately a bijection with skew SSYTs leading to a crystal structure and Schur positivity of the generalized coinvariant algebra from the Delta conjecture (with G. Benkart, L. Colmenarejo, P. Harris, R. Orellana, A. Schiling, M. Yip).

 

This project had a broader impact with its immediate application towards Theoretical Computer Science, and connections with Statistical Mechanics in the asymtptotics study. It involved collaborations with several postdocs and graduate students, and lead to new projects for graduate students.
